responses.text: Trees have green stuff in their leaves called chlorophyll.
In fall, the green goes away and you see other colors.
Yellow and orange were hiding under the green all along.
Some trees like pine trees stay green because they have a different kind of leaf.

Chlorophyll.text: Chlorophyll is a green pigment found in plants that absorbs light energy for photosynthesis.
Chlorophyll.title: Chlorophyll

Autumn_leaf_color.text: Autumn leaf color is a phenomenon that affects the green leaves of many trees, causing them to change color.
Autumn_leaf_color.title: Autumn leaf color

Carotenoid.text: Carotenoids are yellow, orange, and red pigments present in leaves throughout the year.
Carotenoid.title: Carotenoid

Evergreen.text: An evergreen is a plant that has leaves throughout the year. Pine trees have needle-like leaves with a waxy coating that prevents water loss.
Evergreen.title: Evergreen

responses.text: Clouds are not made of cotton or smoke - they are made of water.
Water goes up into the sky when the sun warms it.
Up high it gets cold and the water makes clouds.
Rain falls when the clouds get too heavy.

Cloud.text: A cloud is an aerosol consisting of visible masses of tiny water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere.
Cloud.title: Cloud

Evaporation.text: Evaporation is the process by which water changes from a liquid to a gas.
Evaporation.title: Evaporation

Condensation.text: Condensation is the process where water vapor becomes liquid when air cools.
Condensation.title: Condensation

Precipitation.text: Precipitation is water released from clouds in the form of rain, freezing rain, sleet, snow, or hail.
Precipitation.title: Precipitation

responses.text: Bees fly to flowers and collect sweet juice called nectar.
They bring it back to their hive and turn it into honey.
Honey is stored in little wax boxes inside the hive.
Bees sting when they feel scared, so be gentle around them.

Nectar.text: Nectar is a sugar-rich liquid produced by flowers to attract pollinators.
Nectar.title: Nectar

Beehive.text: A beehive is an enclosed structure in which honey bees live and raise their young.
Beehive.title: Beehive

Honeycomb.text: Honeycomb is a structure of hexagonal wax cells built by bees to store honey and pollen.
Honeycomb.title: Honeycomb

Bee_sting.text: A bee sting is a wound caused by the stinger of a bee, usually as a defensive response.
Bee_sting.title: Bee sting

responses.text: Worms live in the dirt and make tunnels.
Rain fills up their tunnels so they have to come out.
Worms need to stay wet but not too wet.
If you see a worm on the sidewalk, you can put it in the grass.

Earthworm.text: Earthworms are tube-shaped segmented worms that live in soil and create tunnels.
Earthworm.title: Earthworm

Cutaneous_respiration.text: Cutaneous respiration is breathing through the skin, which requires moisture.
Cutaneous_respiration.title: Cutaneous respiration

responses.text: Some animals sleep all winter long - this is called hibernation.
Bears, chipmunks, and groundhogs all hibernate.
They eat lots of food before winter to get fat.
The fat gives them energy while they sleep.

Hibernation.text: Hibernation is a state of minimal activity and metabolic depression in animals during winter.
Hibernation.title: Hibernation

Hyperphagia.text: Hyperphagia is a period of excessive eating before hibernation.
Hyperphagia.title: Hyperphagia

Adipose_tissue.text: Adipose tissue, or body fat, stores energy for later use.
Adipose_tissue.title: Adipose tissue
